ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Intractable Epilepsy with Bilateral Cortical Involvement
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of mixed seizure disorder since infancy; pre-operative bilateral central auditory deficits attributed to diffuse epileptic activity.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Corpus Callosum Disconnection (Split-Brain Syndrome)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Surgical sectioning of the corpus callosum resulted in classic disconnection deficits (left ear dichotic deficit, bilateral pattern deficit).

ordered_list.rationale_short: Evaluate interhemispheric transfer and central auditory function pre- and post-commissurotomy.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Pre-operative evaluation revealed normal peripheral hearing but symmetrical bilateral deficits on central auditory tests. This pattern implicated bilateral cortical involvement, likely secondary to the patient's long-standing diffuse epileptic activity.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Speech recognition scores were 90% or better bilaterally.

tests.name: Central Auditory Processing Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Symmetrical bilateral deficits observed on Dichotic Digits, SSW (~45%), and Frequency Patterns (~65%).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Two weeks following posterior commissurotomy, a marked change in central auditory function was observed. A classic split-brain pattern emerged: the left ear showed profound deficits in dichotic tasks due to disconnection from the language-dominant hemisphere, while the right ear improved to normal levels due to release from central competition. Frequency pattern recognition degraded bilaterally.

tests.name: Central Auditory Processing Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Marked change: Right ear SSW improved to ~90% (release from competition); Left ear SSW worsened to ~0-5%; Frequency Patterns worsened bilaterally to <10%.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Two weeks following anterior commissurotomy (5 months after the first surgery), central auditory test results were essentially unchanged from the post-posterior commissurotomy findings. This confirmed that the auditory fibers of the corpus callosum are located in the posterior half.

tests.name: Central Auditory Processing Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Results essentially unchanged from the post-posterior commissurotomy findings (Right ear ~90%, Left ear ~0-5% on dichotic tasks; FP <10%).

proposed_items: Audiological monitoring of central function pre- and post-surgery
counseling_actions: Explain that peripheral hearing sensitivity remains normal.
Counsel on significant difficulty in noisy environments or when different people are speaking to each ear simultaneously.
Explain that the left ear will struggle to process speech in competing noise due to the disconnection between the right hemisphere and the language center.
Discuss the improvement in the right ear as a result of release from central auditory competition.

escalation.rationale_short: Routine monitoring of central auditory status following neurosurgery.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor the effects of partial and complete commissurotomy on central auditory processing.
